div.p: Your, my Bullinger, is my authority to write now; for he has announced about the messenger and has urged me to write very dutifully. I am well by the grace of God, although I am in great labors and do not have my comforts here, which I am accustomed to elsewhere.

In these 40 days, I have been able to complete many things here and begin others, all of which you will see. I had almost decided to stay here until Christmas; but I am recalled to the duchy and am forced to go, even if the plague rages everywhere. If only I had your spirit at least in this matter and did not fear it! If anyone seeks me, they will be informed of my return to Tübingen, although I will not be there for long. Let him come there, who wants to see me; for at least he will find my people. Again, there is a rumor of future assemblies, and I think they will finally happen. But another rumor brings not a very happy message: that persecution is growing in England and that Philip is attempting an alliance with some princes and bishops of Germany. May God destroy their plans!

The money sent here by our duke is still n... If I do not come there myself this winter, I will undoubtedly send one of my people, who will handle some matters there, and indeed I will send him soon or I will come myself soon. Greet the noblemen and all the brothers. I would like you to share this letter with Mr. Laelius, to whom I send my warmest regards. Strasbourg, November 14.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, Antistes of Zürich, my most honored brother.
I beg you, send the brief catalog of heretics, in which you were of course omitted, and also send your letter, which you wrote to me about it.
